pullRequest.body:
Redefines `IsAlgebraic` and `IsRelational` as `abbrev`s, removing the need for some explicit instances.
The constructors for `Structure`, `LHom` and `LHom.IsExpansionOn` will, by default, skip the definition on relations in algebraic languages and the definition on functions in relational languages.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [d20a8d9148](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16323/commits/d20a8d9148ff8388175bd2d4ceba1838cdc30c24)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`- instance [L.IsAlgebraic] {n : â„•} : IsEmpty (L.Relations n)`
`- instance [L.IsRelational] {n : â„•} : IsEmpty (L.Functions n)`
`- isAlgebraic_empty`
`- isAlgebraic_of_empty_relations`
`- isRelational_empty`
`- isRelational_of_empty_functions`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

There are potentially other default values that could work for `LHom.IsExpansionOn`, whose fields are `Prop`s. I can't really think of any other default values for `Structure` and `LHom`, as those are data, so a default only makes sense when the domains are empty.

Currently, the only languages where these shortcuts are helpful are `Language.empty` and `Language.ring`. I think I want to shift the other explicit languages (`Language.order` and `Language.graph`) to use a definition similar to `Language.ring`, in which case they will also be able to use these shortcuts.

Yes, that makes a lot of sense

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10699189972/job/29660180078)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10699189972/job/29660181644)

```suggestion
  map_onFunction :
    âˆ€ {n} (f : L.Functions n) (x : Fin n â†’ M), funMap (Ï•.onFunction f) x = funMap f x := by
      exact fun {n} => (IsRelational.empty_functions _).elim
  map_onRelation :
    âˆ€ {n} (R : L.Relations n) (x : Fin n â†’ M), RelMap (Ï•.onRelation R) x = RelMap R x := by
      exact fun {n} => (IsAlgebraic.empty_relations _).elim
```
also do you need the `by exact` at all? Are they an elaboration trick?

It doesn't work when I don't use the `by exact`.
If I just try to use `IsAlgebraic`, say, to define something, it will (rightly) complain that there is no `IsAlgebraic` instance. If it's wrapped in `by exact`, it's willing to try and see whether there is an `IsAlgebraic` instance around.
Okay, so they are an elaboration trick

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(ModelTheory): Better uses of `IsAlgebraic` and `IsRelational`
